turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Parris, you may continue.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Thank you.

In answer to Mr. Justice Stewart's questions as to the termination notice referred to in 6A, that is actually a purely ministerial pro forma act in order to indicate to the various county departments such as the treasurer and personnel that determination has taken place.
Otherwise, you'd have people continued on the pensions and payroll.
It's really a bookkeeping type of a thing.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Parris --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Whether --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- were -- were these people part time?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Just part time.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes, part time.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Did they practice on this side?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What is the -- is -- is your -- you -- you tell us as a matter of fact and of law that these people's employment automatically expired subjected to only to this ministerial certification of that fact.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: At the time that the -- that -- that the public defender himself, left office.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
I think the best example can be myself, because I'm the County Attorney of Rockland County.
I have similar employees in the exempt class, attorneys, assistant county attorneys.
I hope to be reappointed next month.
I will be then retaining these employees who will then have to go and swear an oath.
If they had some sort of a continuation, why would they have to swear their oath again next month after I retain them?
It's because --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You say you'll --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: -- they serve at my pleasure.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- you'll reappointment them, not (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: That's if I reappointment them.
Then they have to go and swear an oath.
Now, why would they have to do that?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do they receive --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: They serve at my pleasure.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When they're originally appointed, do they receive a document or a certificate, something like the one that the President gives to the members of his cabinet which ends with the words, “At the pleasure of the President?”

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: I don't believe so, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: They don't get any piece of paper?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the law says it.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Excuse me.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The law says it though.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes, the law does.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That they serve at his pleasure.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What, is that a statute or an ordinance or what?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
Of course, there is no statute.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, is there an ordinance that says at his pleasure?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Well, it's through the Civil Service Department of the State of New York, interpreted by our personnel director.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So what does it say?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Well, as he states in --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Where do we find that in the record?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Page 138.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yes, that's what I have here.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: The appendix toward the bottom.
The question, “Is there such a thing as a permanent appointment of an exempt man so that he can remain in office and succeed as appointing authority?”
Answer, “No, sir.”
Question, “When individual is appointed to an exempt position, he's required to take an oath of office, is he not?”
Answer, “All employees are required to take an oath of office including those appointed to the exempt class position -- position.”

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What did the District Court have to say on this subject, do you remember?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Well, I would refer also -- you had asked the -- the question as to Judge Broderick on 25A.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: And above he -- he does state the third and final requirement of the Elrod concurrence that the attempt to remove plaintiffs from their jobs have been based upon -- on the sole ground of their political beliefs.
But down about six lines from the -- the bottom of that same page, he writes, “The incident was not a ground for defendant's decision not to renew plaintiff, Finkel.”

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, and then his -- his caption for that section of his opinion is "Plaintiffs were not reappointed."
But is there any -- beyond that, is there any -- are there any findings of the District Court in which you remember on this --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- subject?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Parris, could I ask you a question of you about this?
You said that they would have to take -- your people have to take an oath in the new term.
Well, this testimony doesn't say that and those statutes says if you call to it, why do you say they have to take a new oath?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: It's by civil service law.
They announced serving --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: for a new --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- what in civil service law says that?
What if they just stayed on and nothing was done.
As I understand, the way this is written, he -- he began the process of executing termination notices for six of the nine assistants who had served under Barone.
I -- I thought you under -- he indicated if he had done nothing, they would have just continued on the payroll, wouldn't they?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: It may have, but they wouldn't have continued --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: There's nothing in the law that says they would not have stayed on the payroll, is there, if he'd done nothing?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: They may not -- they -- they could have by error because the ministerial act wasn't --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, how do we know it's error?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: -- didn't take place.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: How do we know it's error?
Your witness doesn't say that and the law doesn't say that and regulations don't say it.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Well, basically, I know that because the fact that I'm the County Attorney and I'm --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And that you're required --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: -- I'm involved --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: A requirement that you imposed, right?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Well, it's an involvement that I know because I handled these matters.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if you didn't impose that requirement at all and nothing at all was done --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- is it not true they would continue just to get their paychecks in the ordinary routine to continue to do their work?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: No, Your Honor, because they serve at the pleasure of an appointing authority.
That is stated in Mr. Anderson, uncontroverted testimony.
If the person is gone and you're serving that person and his term ends, they also self-destruct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But isn't that necessarily the predicate for the District Court's judgment that you couldn't fire them, that they couldn't be fired for the political beliefs.
That their term lasted beyond the expiration of the term --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I believe --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- of a public defender.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: That was an error.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So don't -- don't you think the -- the -- don't you think the District Court read New York law and saying their term does not end with -- with the term of the public defender?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Maybe there was an error on the part of Judge Broderick.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, behind -- I know but we don't usually second guess district judges about state law.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: I understand that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Counsel, what -- what about page 32 (a) of the appendix.

I -- I'm wondering how -- how semantically and how substantive this discussion we've been having as where you have Footnote 10, where Judge Broderick says, “The fact that plaintiffs are removable at the will of the public defender is of course irrelevant to the -- the determination of the constitutional issue prevented herein.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do you see a -- substantive distinction between a person being removable at will and a person whose term expires at a given point?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes, I do Your Honor.
And I would like the Court to take notice of Judge Hall's concurrence in (Inaudible) because he made a point to that, that this -- it's not a termination.
There's a difference if you're going to talk about someone you're not rehiring.

For instance, to really -- it comes down to -- that I think is that sponsorship to -- to nine vacant positions, absence the coercion in Elrod, leaves me to believe that you couldn't violate anyone's constitutional right.
Where is the -- this right of liberty?
Does it extend to someone who has another job and who is just not rehired?
And I believe that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I suppose that you could argue that reading -- that it's fair to read Judge Broderick's opinion as saying it doesn't make any difference whether it's a -- whether -- whether the term expired or not.
That failure to reappoint is subject to the same constitutional rule as -- as if the term was held to extend until fired.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And I've -- if that is the -- and if -- if that poses a completely different question if he held that.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Well, yes, but --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And I'm sure you -- you would say that.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes.
I would also like to return if I may to the question of expectancy.
We have the case here where one of the respondents, Mr. Finkel, changes registration to a Democrat, several months prior to January 1978.
That doesn't sound like someone who has the expectancy, an objective expectancy --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it didn't work --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: -- of returning.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it didn't work.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Excuse me.
It didn't work.
Yes, Your Honor, obviously.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You -- you haven't mentioned anything yet and I hope you will at some point at your convenience, of the policy relationship that exists between the management of the office and all of the staff.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes, I plan to, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No.
Do it at your own time.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: As -- as part time employees.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That's correct, yes.
Also, historically, respondents had sought some people in this office that had been rehired and others that hadn't been.
They both tried and used political friends to try to receive recommendations.
It doesn't sound like someone with an objective expectancy --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: -- like imperatives.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Could I as -- could I ask you?
Suppose the terms did expire and the public defender -- a new public defender put out a notice on the wall and said, “Only -- only Democrats need to apply or only Republicans need to apply.
I'm just not interested in hiring anybody but Democrats.
Does Elrod cover a situation like that or not?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: It may in that case, but that's not what happened --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, of course it wasn't alright --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: -- here.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- was it?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: No it was in Elrod rule.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, are -- are you referring to the plurality in Elrod or -- or to the -- there was several separate opinions in Elrod.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: As to which issue that --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: As to -- in your response to my Brother White.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: I think, it made it --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, let's -- let's assume that these employees, everybody agreed to these employees were -- were policymaking and confidential, let's just assume that they -- or that -- that they were not.
Assume they were not.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Policymaking or confidential and they put on -- you put on the sign on the wall, “Only Democrats need apply.
We're -- we're in a process of rehiring and your terms have expired, but none of you who is an -- who is a Republican need apply.”
Does Elrod cover that or not?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: I think if the Court wanted to extend it to that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, so you say, it doesn't.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It doesn't --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: No, it might.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The -- the Elrod judgment was -- was supported by five members of this Court.
Three joined in one opinion and which is -- I'd call them correctly, the plurality opinion and two joined the judgment based upon another considerably shorter opinion.

And that second opinion joined the judgment only on the basis of the proposition that an employee cannot be discharged or threatened with a discharge from a job that he is satisfactorily performing upon the sole ground of his political beliefs.
And if there is no discharge here, then as you say, you'd have to extend out if it's not covered by Elrod and -- and Elrod would have to be extended to cover it.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: I agree with you, Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that correct?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: And one -- one very important point here, we talk about solely for political reasons.
I'd like to point out that there were two Democrats in that whole -- an office which who were not rehired.
One of the people that was -- were rehired is a registered blank.
And -- and in fact, the record also shows that my client had spoken to a Republican legislator about -- he was very interest in law secretary -- Republican law secretary.
And Legislator (Inaudible), a Republican, stated, “I'm not interested in him, he has a job.
I want to find a job for Tabakman.
So there was, I think, no denial of political beliefs in the sense of they're being Republicans.
What you had was as I see it, nine vacant positions, 280 some odd attorneys in Rockland County, all with a possibility, if they could qualify as criminal attorneys.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Could the public defender on his own decide that he does not want to have part time assistance anymore and just abolish the positions?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
It would have to be done by the legislature of Rockland County.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The -- the legislation itself, fixes part time and full time?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes, sir.
They could change it to full time and again, they do control that.
It's the power of the person.
They could have three assistants or nine assistants, it's the local legislature.
Now, as we stated before, we don't believe we have to show a compelling state interest, because we don't believe that any constitutional right was lost.
In fact however, we believe we have shown a compelling state interest in that attorneys are special.
I think this Court recognized that attorneys were special in Bates versus the State Bar of Arizona.
They're special in our civic, cultural and political life.
I would like the Court to envision a political ladder, right here.
At the bottom rung, our assistant county attorneys, assistant public defenders, assistant attorney generals.
Up atop, the U.S. Congressman, U.S. Senators, Governors, and of course, judges.
And I think this Court will recognize that attorneys do have a higher proportionate share than other occupations and professions as to these high and lofty positions.

What I'm saying is if you affirm the local court decisions, you will effectively set up an entry barrier, the young, intelligent, ambitious male and female, black and white attorneys from starting on that ladder and moving up to those lofty positions.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did you make that argument below?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: No, Your Honor, because below we believe that there was no constitutional right that was lost and we didn't have to show a compelling state interest.
But I think it's an important interest.
I think that myself -- and this is really why I'm here, because I do believe in a patronage system, our patronage system in Rockland County, a moderate one.
And I'm an example of it, so is my co-counsel, Mr. Apotheker.
I start -- in 1974, the Democrats took over the legislature in Rockland County, the majority.
And I was appointed assistant county attorney.
From there, I moved to first deputy county attorney.
Two years ago, I became county attorney.
Leaders have spoken to me recently about running me for state office and possibly a county court judgeship.
Mr. Apotheker was just recently elected to a town justice seat in Haverstraw.
And that's what I'm talking about in the ladder.
I don't want to leave the ladder to the rich who don't need the political machinery.
They don't need the party strength to move up that ladder.
They can skip all the rungs.
They can go straight with their money and run for U.S. Senator or Congressman.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What's wrong with your arguing that kind of an issue is not also assuming this has -- is relevant.
Would it not be equally relevant that this is related to the existence of a two-party system?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Absolutely.

I believe in the two-party system and I believe that both parties in Rockland County, Democrats and Republicans, just would be able to attract these intelligent, young and yes, ambitious attorneys to move up this ladder.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The question still lands whether that's relevant to the issues in this case however.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Maybe, Your Honor, but something I wanted to say to this Court because I deeply believe it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What happens to the point of independent lawyer who doesn't belong to either party?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Well, I say through that party system, but attorneys generally as they come out of the law school to a great extent, most of them do get involved in politics.
That's why they're different than deputy sheriffs and janitors and we recognize --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So he is --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: -- that in Bates.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So the nonpartisan lawyer becomes a janitor?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Not necessarily, Your Honor.
He'd still have a right to run, but runs --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And end up a janitor?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: [Laughs] No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where is Rockland County?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) I don't see why think the special privilege of party member?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Party -- I don't know.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I don't see where you get that in the Constitution.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Well, in the Constitution, but it -- it's a -- Court can take judicial notice of the importance of the two-party system.
It has been for the past 200 years.
Recommendations of patronage, whatever you want, isn't all about public and our private lives, everyone recommends someone for something.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I know of a very great prosecuting attorney in New York that had both parties endorsement every time he ran.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: That is quite often.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, isn't -- isn't the real question not whether the -- the patronage system is desirable or undesirable or whether New York has chosen or not, but this was a civil rights action where Judge Broderick felt -- found that Rockland County's application of it violated the Federal Constitution.
And unless it violates the Federal Constitution, New York is free to choose its bizarre system of promotion as it -- as it wants.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So far as -- so far as the federal courts are concerned.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes, I -- but I believe this Court should be following as I said before, the reasoning and especially Judge Hall's concurrence because there, I think there's a tremendous resemblance between (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: -- and this case.
In both cases, you don't have the coercion of Elrod.
And in both cases, you have terms that came to an end.
Yes, in (Inaudible) was by statute.
But it was and also the question of -- in (Inaudible) of a small office looking for loyalty as opposed to the Deputy Sheriff -- Sheriff's Office in Cook County which was 3000 or 4000 employees.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where is Rockland County, Mr. Parris?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: It's 30 miles north in New York City -- northwest of New York City.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Northwest, is it only (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: It's -- it's across the Tappan Zee Bridge from Westchester County and right above New Jersey.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The Tappan Zee Bridge comes into Rockland County.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Correct, from Westchester.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: South of Bear Mountian Bridge.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Exactly, exactly.

As to the relationship of the public defender and his assistants and as to whether a public -- a public defender is in fact a policymaker, I've a great deal of problem because I really -- from the time I read Elrod, I've been troubled by what this Court meant by policymaking confidential.
I think that the lower court decisions, legal periodicals are all in the same position.

Possibly Harvard Law Review is closest when they said janitors and elevator operators definitely not -- are not, department heads probably are, and everyone between would have to be decided on a case by case basis by the Court.
I think that -- one point I'd like to make is that the assistants are the alter ego.
They are the extension of the public defender.
They are and these -- just 23 justice courts around the county and they are the public defender when they walk into those courts.
So there is an extension there.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: We assume --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- U.S. Attorneys there, does their term expire when a new president is inaugurated?

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: I don't know, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, there were some a little brouhaha, but in Philadelphia not so long ago.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Oh, I remember that.
That was --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: (Inaudible)
Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And in New York earlier, but -- but generally, they -- there is a change, isn't there and isn't the --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- they're appointees of the executives or the Justice Department of the United States.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Correct.
And recommend --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you don't know if their term expires.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: No, I'm not sure.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I guess they do some settling.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: I'm not sure, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, the Commission of the United States Attorney as those famous last three words, “To serve at the pleasure of the President,” four words, at the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it is a term of office.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Yes.
I think it -- I think it is.
And as -- and assistant public defenders really live within the term of their appointing authority.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, there's a certain inconsistency, isn't there?
Be -- between the two facts which leads we, apparently believe to be the facts that you serve at the pleasure of an official for a term of four years --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Which is it?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: In -- in --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: I don't --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: -- the U.S. Attorney I think it's both.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you have -- and the four years can expire and if you aren't reappointed, you're through.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: In the case of the assistant public defenders or assistance county attorneys, sir?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No.
No, no --

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Oh, just --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- the U.S. Attorney.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Oh, I'm not familiar with that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The United States Attorneys.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: As -- as I was stating that I had this problem about the public defender, but I would like to give this example possibly because I'm not sure whether the public defender is a policy holder or who is the policy holder.
Is it just the legislator and his confidential secretary?
Is it a judge and his law secretary and then what about the others in an office?
I thought about this and I took the example of the possibility of a public defender stating, “We'll have no more pleas on marijuana cases."
And he gives that to his assistant public defenders.
And they go into the courts to implement that policy.
But he's the one up in front.
He's the one in the courts.
He sees the witnesses and judges the jury.
And when he comes back and they discuss it in the public defender's office and he states that, “On this case Chief, we must take a plea.
I've seen that witness.
I've seen that judge.
You -- this one, we're going to change your policy.”
Are they not in a confidential relationship within the making, the implementing and the changing of a policy?
I'll reserve whatever time I have left to -- for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Proceed, counsel.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

I would like to begin by addressing myself to the issue that was being dealt with by Mr. Justice Stewart, just before the lunch and recess, which is the question of the permanency of the appointments of -- of assistant public defenders.
I think the record will show, firstly, Mr. Finkel was appointed with less than a year remaining in the term of his appointing public defender, Arnold Becker.
Page 94 of the record further shows that Mr. Finkel left another job to take that job.

And he testified not only that he believe his appointment permanent, subject only to the right of the public defender to discharge him for improperly performing his job, but that he would not have left one job to go to another job with only nine months of tenure remaining.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, counsel, what do you make of Footnote 10 in Judge Broderick's opinion at page 32A of the appendix, the fact that the plaintiffs are removable at the will of the public defender, not for a cause but at the will of the public defender?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist, I think the District Court found that it -- that a set term or a lack thereof was irrelevant in his application of Elrod to the fact in this case.
I don't think he decided whether there was or was not a set term.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, the very page of the record to which you referred us indicates of the awareness of the witness that he could be dismissed without a cause which means employment at will.
I'm looking toward the bottom of the page there, the last question and answer.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well, respectfully, Mr. Justice Stewart, this Court has held in the past that while employees can be dismissed for no reason, they cannot be dismissed for the wrong reason.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, I know that, but I was just indicating that this question and answer at -- and without more support, Footnote 10.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: And I might further go on to point out that Mr. Finkel, whatever the procedure is in Mr. Parris' County Attorney's Office, Mr. Finkel testified that when Mr. Barone replaced Mr. Becker, he was not formally reappointed.
He took no formal steps to remain in the office.
He was merely told casually and verbally to stay on.
This is not a far cry from the situation that Mr. Justice White described whether it's a set term and you must take an oath of office or you have no legal standing whatsoever.
The Court, I think, very accurately foresees the situation here.
There's a big void, there is no statutory provision setting a fixed term or an unfixed term for an assistant public defender.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And yet the District Court labeled the whole heading of its opinion on -- beginning on page 25A.
Plaintiffs were not reappointed.

And it's quite a different thing from being discharged and if two of the necessary -- of the five oaths necessary to support a majority judgment in -- in Elrod against Burns, limited themselves to the question of whether it was unconstitutional to discharge people because of their political beliefs.
If these people were not discharged, then Elrod is not applicable.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Then, Your Honor, I would refer back to Perry v. Sindermann where there's a very similar situation.
There was a -- an unwritten agreement in -- in essence that untenured teachers in fact did by tradition, have tenure.
The --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But Sindermann had a contract, didn't he, year -- year by year?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Yes, which expired if -- if I recall the facts correctly, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And meaning for 10 consecutive years which, as I recall the courts not created an expectancy of continuation to -- at least that was a factor.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I might respectfully point out that Mr. Finkel who was in the public defender's office for seven years saw under Mr. Becker four Republicans and four Democrats.
Under Mr. Barone, approximately the same mix, 4, 4 and 1 unregistered.
And certainly, Mr. Tabakman who came in later had the same expectation that succeeding public defenders would continue the nonpartisan policy of the office.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, is that in the record somewhere?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Excuse me.
The number of --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No, no, his expectation that -- that this in fact, whatever the law was.
In fact, this was a -- an appointment of indefinite duration.
Is that in the record anywhere?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Yes.
Mr. Finkel testified explicitly that he thought that the appointment was permanent.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where is this?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: I believe it's on page -- pages 76 and 77 of the appendix and also page 94 on either recross or redirected, I believe Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, on page 77, there's the question about the middle of the page, “Did you approach Mr. Barone about being retained in your position?”
Answer, “No, he just continued me in office."

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: And I submit, Mr. Justice Rehnquist that militates against the set term, the fact that there was no formal requirement of taking a new oath or any formal requirement other than just remaining in the same office doing the same job for a new boss.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But the answer was, “He continued me in office,” not, I remained in office.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well, I can see the wording -- I -- I concede the wording which of course implies as we have conceded that these assistants serve at the pleasure of the public defender.
But it also indicates to me if that there's a continuing employment in the absence of an action on the -- on the part of a Mr. Branti, who attempts to terminate.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, let me ask you this.

Is your basic claim that this is a Perry against Sindermann and Roth versus Board of Regents type of case where even though the people had no job tenure claim, they were fired for the exercise of a constitutional right of free speech or an Elrod against Burns case, or do you see no distinction between the two?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, we took the position in the District Court that these were in effect continued employments.
They were not as in (Inaudible) set by statute at a fixed term.
The District Court judge as I interpreted his decision, took no position on that.He --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Evidence, said it made no difference --

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Exactly judge --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- even --

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: -- White --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- even if -- even if their terms expire, with the public defender's term, the failure to reappoint them for this kind of a reason was constitutionally wrong.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: That is correct, Mr. Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then that's the -- that's the judgment you're defending here?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
And in view of the fact that the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But that's not covered by -- that's not covered by Elrod at all, is it?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: As you were and that's not what the District Court said at all.

At page 25A he said, “The third and final requirement of the concurrence in Elrod is that the attempt to remove plaintiffs from their jobs have been based upon the sole ground of their political beliefs, I find that this requirement has been satisfied.
Is -- doesn't that a finding that the only reason that they -- for the removal was their political beliefs?
That's the way the Court of Appeals interpret on page 2 (a).
The Court of Appeals said, “Judge Broderick found that appellant had attempted to terminate their employment on the sole ground of their political beliefs.”

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but the question is --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why would we concede something else?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you don't take any position -- you say the District Judge didn't take any position on whether it was a termination or a renewal.
That's -- that's what you say.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Stevens, as I read Footnote 10, Justice Broderick says, the fact that these plaintiffs are removable at will is irrelevant to the determination of the constitutional issue.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Exactly --

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Therefore, I don't think Judge Broderick reached that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you're -- so you're saying even if this was a failure to reappoint, even if their terms had expired and it -- and it was only a failure to reappoint, the fact that they -- that they've refused to reappoint because of their political beliefs is constitutionally wrong like the District Court concluded.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You mean Elrod doesn't -- Elrod covers it if they're -- unless they're confidential or policymaking?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
I believe Elrod read in conjunction with Perry.
The expectation of continued employment I believe covers a situation.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but that, then don't you have to argue here that or sustain the -- the holding below that these positions were not in fact confidential or policymaking?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
And I believe that first of all, the District Court did so find and the Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed that finding.S

econdly, I think although my learned adversary has made much of the fact that lawyers are not janitors, effect which I will be the first to concede, these lawyers are very unlike other lawyers in Government.
These are not people who give advice to town boards, to zoning boards, they are not hired by the Government to advise the Government.
They are hired by the Government to represent individual indigent defendants.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, what about --

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: They --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- what about a situation where the -- the new public defender comes in and says from the new policy of this office for which I am responsible will be that we will take no guilty pleas at all or alternatively, he says the policy of this office will be that your or to direct all your efforts to negotiate a plea.
We've got to get this calendar moving.
Now, does that not involve very high policy in terms of operating that office?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: The public defender himself, yes.
But he has instructed his assistant public defenders as to what they can and cannot do.
In fact, Mr. Parris gave a hypothetical example.
I can give the Court an actual example.

The District Attorney in Rockland County has established a policy that he will not accept pleas to a lesser offense in cases of driving well intoxicated where the blood alcohol reading is in excess of .20.
This is a policy that all his assistant district attorneys must follow.
The District Attorney like the public defender himself says the policy.
The assistants disobey that policy at their peril and they are subject as the plurality in Elrod pointed out, to dismissal for cause.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, but how -- how is the prosecutor or the public defender, the head of the staff going to follow what each one, was it nine assistants, is going to do on each specific case.
In many instances, that assistant will be handling 10 or 20 cases in one day?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think we -- I think we're drawing the distinction here between case by case discretion which both Mr. Barone and Mr. Branti indicated that individual assistant public defenders have and broad -- the broad overall goals of the office as referred to in the plurality where the public defender says, “It shall be the goal of our office to concentrate on marijuana, police, driving while intoxicated, whatever you choose, and then it is up to his employees to follow that broad policy scope, but they do not decide in the initial instance what the policy of the office will be.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, my question -- my point was, is it possible, feasible, with the volume of cases you'd have in these relatively minor offenses to monitor what each one is doing or is he not entitled to have -- select a person of his own choice in whom he has confidence and sure knowledge that they'll carry out his policies.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well, this --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is that a factor in this case?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, I think the -- the Sheriff in Elrod was entitled to sheriff's deputies who followed his policy directives.
And of course, any employer is entitled to have loyal employees.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, I thought you had already -- I thought you had already conceded that there's quite a difference between the deputy sheriff and a lawyer.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: There is a difference on a general basis, but when you -- when you look at the specific duties that these gentlemen performed, is there such a great difference between trying a case -- an individual case on a case by case basis within the guidelines laid down by the public defender and the decisions made by a deputy sheriff.
The deputy sheriff has the decision of life and death over a fleeing perpetuator.
There are -- any job that involves any degree of discretion, there are some case by case policy decisions to be made.
For example, the deputy sheriffs maybe instructed.
Always fire one warning shot before you shoot at -- at a fleeing felon, or never fire your firearm under certain circumstances.
That is a policy directive.
Or they may be given a certain latitude with regard to whether they used their firearm in -- in isolated areas or metropolitan areas.
These case by case decisions, I submit, are not the policy making referred to by this Court in Elrod.
There is always in practically any occupation, some degree of case by case review by the individual.

Now, Mr. Parris, my learned adversary, indicated in some detail the value of a system which enables young attorneys to enter the political system and in effect get a leg up into politics and like Mr. Parris, I got my start in politics the same way, I don't quarrel with that system.
However, that is not the way it works.

Of the appointees made to these positions, they were -- the people as Mr. Justice Marshall pointed out who were the mature, the politically active, the successful who were able to get these favorite jobs --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Who said that?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Your Honor, indicated, I may have stretched your point a little bit, [Laughter] but Your Honor indicated --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I thought there were quite a few independent unregistered lawyers and I know personally that are pretty good lawyers and making a pretty good living.
And he didn't have to join any party.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Your Honor, I thought your point was that in order to get ahead in politics, you had to join one of the parties.
I must say, you don't make a good living without it.
But you have to be a member --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You could not say that and I don't believe that.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well, I'm sorry I misconstrued Your Honor's comments in that case.

But the -- that does not take away from the point that I was attempting to make which is essentially that it is not the young attorneys fresh out of law school, who get these positions, because they -- with rare exceptions, unless they have some family political influence, they are not in a position to obtain these appointments.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is the pay pretty good for these things in Rockland County and some parts of the country.
It's pretty much pro bono almost --

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it's a fixed salary.

The reason that it is part time is because as Mr. Parris indicated, there are 23 justice courts and it's more important to have a relatively large number of part time employees than fewer full time employees because a lot of this is night work.
And with 23 courts to be covered, it's necessary to have a large number of personnel available several evenings a week and plus days in the office.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do they work fixed hours or how's their time?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Your Honor, my understanding is they're -- they're assigned two days a week in the office, plus each attorney is assigned certain specific courts in which they appear and handle regular calendars.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In the evenings?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Some are evenings, some are day sessions.
It depends on when the individual court happens to sit.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think this is any different in some county rule that says where in the next year, we're probably going to have 10 public construction projects, but only Democrats or Republicans need -- need been on these -- or limit to bidding opportunities to Democrats or Republicans?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: I think that's exactly the situation here as the District Court found.
No one who did not receive the sponsorship of the Democratic caucus which consisted of the majority of the county legislature was considered for employment as an assistant public defender.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, if you made --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do you think a --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- the issue here, then it's not covered Elrod against Burns, is it?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: I believe, Your Honor, it is.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: A construction job isn't the same as -- as a confidential or policymaking assistant.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Your Honor, I don't believe that these gentlemen are policy making or confidential.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It may be, but for the reason hindered by -- suggested my -- by my Brother Stewart, I don't think the answer to the question about whether construction jobs are assigned only to Democrats or Republicans, answers the question of whether one may choose only Republicans or Democrats for confidential or policymaking position.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Your Honor, I agree with you perfectly, if these were in fact confidential or policymaking positions.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it does get you across the bridge that there's no difference between discharge and reappointment.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: I believe that that is what Perry read with Elrod in effect, says.
I don't think that there's a significant constitutional distinction between holding and serving in a position that you're serving in well whether that is a fixed term or a -- I mean determinate term.
I do not for a moment concede that there's a fixed term in this instance.
I think it's an indeterminate term.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Wagner, on that point, your witness, Mr. Finkel, said he thought he had a permanent appointment.
Did that mean until he reached retirement age or -- or what does it mean?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice Powell.

I believe if you -- if you read his testimony in context with some later cross-examination, he realized he served at the pleasure of the public defender, but that he would not be terminated as long as he did his job properly.
This was the experience under the two prior public defenders of Rockland County.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's a different -- that's a different point in saying I -- that's a much stronger expectation than saying, I serve at his will and he can fire me for any reason he wants to accept my political beliefs.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well, isn't that what this Court has said that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well that's -- that's a different -- still, nevertheless it's considerably different from what you have said.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Someone who serves at will can be terminated for no reason, but not an improper reason and I would submit --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's as far as you need to go, I guess.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: You're saying he can only be fired for cause, is that the substance of -- of your view?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well, I wouldn't go quite that far, Mr. Justice Powell.
I would -- I would say that he cannot be fired for a constitutionally impermissible reason

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, couldn't he be fired to replace him with his brother?
I mean that's not --

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, I think it was --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that's not for a cause, is it?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: That's -- no, that's why I would not go as far as to say only for cause.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: I will not go any further with the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you would -- you would say that if -- that he couldn't fire him because of his political beliefs.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: You're right.
I will not go any further than to say he cannot be fired for constitutionally impermissible reasons.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Would he have an entitlement to a due process hearing before being fired, passing on that?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: If -- if he is discharged -- if he is discharged allegedly for cause.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Well, yes.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Not statutorily, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: But constitutionally?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: I believe that that whether would be a constitutional right to that, but not with the statute.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If -- if he -- if he had alleged that he was then fired for an unconstitutional reason, then --

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- then maybe you --

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: If it were alleged that he had in some way improperly performed his duties and he claimed he had not improperly performed them, I believe he would be entitled to a hearing.
Certainly, there's an --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why would you say that -- why would you say?

You just concede -- what if he said -- what if he said, “Well, I was fired -- I was doing my job well, but I was fired because -- not because I didn't do my job well, but because he want to replace me with my brother.”
He wouldn't get any hearing.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: No, that's correct.
I -- I said, Your Honor, if he were allegedly dismissed for improperly performing his duties, he would have a hearing.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I can see that.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: That would be discharge for a cause.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: He's not entitled to be discharge only for a cause.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: No.
Again, Your Honor, I will have to fall back on my statement that he can be discharged for any reason except an impermissible one, except the constitutionally abhorrent reason.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, and -- and what are those --

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: -- that are involved in this case?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Specifically in this case, as the District Court found, these assistant public defenders were not continued in their employment solely because they were not members of the majority political party in Rockland County and were not sponsored by members of that party.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Okay.
Then you've got to show in addition to that, that they were not confidential or policymaking officials.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Absolutely, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and that is what exactly what we contend, that they are -- the District Court so found, the Court of Appeals affirmed that finding, they are case by case representatives of the indigent.
They do not make Government policy.
They do not advise Government boards.
They do not even advise the public defender other than to say, “Here I am, give my files to go to court, and I'll represent the indigent.”
That is --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well -- well, what if one of them comes into the public defender and says, I think we've got a real problem with judge so and so in such and such a precinct.
And I think we ought to try to transfer all the cases we can out of that precinct to another one.
Now, isn't there some sort of confidentiality there?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: I don't believe there's anymore confidentiality there than a deputy sheriff for police officer saying so and so's bar in downtown Rockland County is a hangout for young alcoholics and there are fights there every night, we ought to increase our police --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or that we're having trouble getting search warrants from the certain judge.

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Exactly, Your Honor.

It's -- again, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, I think that is a recommendation to a policymaker which may or may not be acted on the public defender, still has the absolute right to say you're wrong, we're not going to do it.
He makes the policy.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But faithfully, a confidential employee is the one who makes a recommendation to a policy maker and not in himself will recommend a policymaker.
Isn't not so?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: I believe that that was Judge Broderick's definition of confidentiality which I think is a good one.

One who stands in a confidential relationship to a policymaker, but he as I limits that to -- for example, a -- the confidential secretary to a town supervisor, a confidential law secretary to a judge, someone with whom there's a very close interaction.
I don't think that as I read Elrod, this confidentiality extends to an entire office of people who were essentially employees.
Undoubtedly, the chief assistant public defender's confidential because he is the alter ego of the public defender just like Mr. Newcomb.
In the Newcomb case, who was the deputy city attorney who had -- who made policy, made law, was in line to succeed as mayor of the City of Milwaukee, I believe it was.
Certainly, he was a policymaker, but the city attorneys under him were not --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you think that the assistant sometimes give legal opinions to their superiors as to what should be done about a case?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

As to what to be done about a case, but that again is, as the plurality points out, decision making on a case by case basis, not broad overall implementation of policy such as concentrated on a particular type of crime --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But if -- if he's doing that, he's in the relationship with the lawyer to a client essentially, is he not?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: I don't believe so, Your Honor.
I think it falls within Mr. Justice White's analogy of the police officer who says, “We're having troubles getting a search warrant from a certain judge.”

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, that's not --

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: It's --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- that's certainly a confidential matter, isn't it, if -- if nothing else?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I would submit that the -- probably, the lowliest clerk at the FBI must keep his information confidential, but does that make him constitutionally unprotected as a policymaker?
I don't believe it does.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, let's -- let's stay with this situation.
An assistant says "Let's keep away from Judge Jones.
He just never will give us a warrant."
Now, is that a confidential communication within that office?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: I believe the communication is confidential, but I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He hopes it is.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: I do not believe that that creates a confidential relationship as this Court meant it in Elrod, because if you're going to make that many employees confidential, then aren't you in a sense -- in -- in essence vitiating the holding in Elrod?
Oh, I think the plurality in Elrod very meticulously detailed the reasons for excluding confidential and policymaking employees and left the others protected by that holding.

And the reason was, as I interpret it, that the policymaking and confidential employees were in a position to, in effect, thwart the goals of the newly appointed public defender or sheriff or whatever.
Whereas, assistant public defenders, the only way that they could embarrass or interrupt the operation of the public defender's office would be if they did not competently perform their jobs.
And then, of course, they could be discharged for cause.
So that, I submit that they do not come in under the heading of those who must be excluded from the Elrod holding because they are in a position to obstruct their supervisors.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Don't you -- don't you think a defense council could throw a case as it were if you know what I mean by that --

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Oh, yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- that is -- and do it -- if he did it skillfully in a way that it would be very difficult to establish that fact?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Well, it maybe different --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He's not very unpopular defendant and the community is aroused and wants that fellow to go to jail and the -- this assistant defenders politically ambitious and -- so he just lets his fellow go down the drain.
It's -- that's a possibility, isn't it?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Of course, it's a possibility, Your Honor.
But then again, he is not properly performing his job, just isn't as --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you think it's easy to -- to monitor that kind of thing?

turn.speaker: david_macrae_wagner
turn.label: Mr. David Macrae Wagner
turn.text: Corruption is never easy to monitor anymore than it's easier to monitor a corrupt deputy sheriff who takes bribes to let felons escape.
It happens.
We try and prevent it, but it's going to happen no matter how hard we try.
I don't think that that's the setting criteria in my opinion.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you have anything further, Mr. Parris?
You have about two minutes left.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: I make -- I make two quick points.

I don't want to leave this Court that -- this Court's be left with the impression that Democrats in Rockland County don't rehire Republicans to of the leading people in the county, Mr. George Ranker (ph) who is director of our order to control is a Republican.
Usually --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There are some, they don't.

turn.speaker: marc_l_parris
turn.label: Mr. Marc L. Parris
turn.text: Some they don't [Laughs], right.

But we have quite a few at the annex to want to leave that impression and I would just leave the Court with -- as to the question of continuation of employment which I think is paramount as was stated by Mr. Justice Stewart in Board of Regents versus Roth, “It stretches the concept too far to suggest that a person is deprived of liberty when he simply is not rehired in one job but remains as free as before to seek another.”
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen, the case is submitted.
We'll hear arguments next in Ford Motor Credit --You don not say that and I don't believe that.
